title: 106_s1704
content: The "Access to High Standards Act" is the short title of this legislation. Congress finds that many students lack academic preparation in secondary school, leading to limited job prospects, high college dropout rates, and the need for remediation. There is a consensus on the importance of raising academic standards and modeling them after advanced placement programs, which are endorsed by many education leaders and half of all States. Advanced placement courses offer 30 college-level courses, are present in 60% of secondary schools, and serve over 1,000,000 students, with test scores accepted for college credit at over 3,000 colleges. The State programs described in paragraph (5) have shown the responsiveness of schools and students to such programs, raised academic standards, and improved outcomes for students in advanced placement courses. The Act aims to encourage more students to take advanced placement exams, highlighting the benefits such as acquiring important skills, higher SAT scores, and better grades in school and college. It also supports efforts to raise academic standards through advanced placement programs to increase student participation and success. The Act aims to increase student participation and success in advanced placement programs by broadening availability, diversifying student participation, providing greater access for low-income students, and increasing access for secondary school juniors. The Act aims to increase student participation in advanced placement programs, with a goal of 25% of secondary school juniors and seniors taking advanced placement courses and receiving college credit for their test scores. SEC. 3. ADVANCED PLACEMENT PROGRAM GRANTS. The Secretary awards grants to eligible entities for 3 years on a competitive basis. Eligible entities are defined as State or local educational agencies. Priority is given to entities showing a need for advanced placement programs and involving business and community organizations. The grant program prioritizes entities that demonstrate a need for advanced placement programs and involve business and community organizations. Grant funds can be used to expand access for low-income individuals to education. Grant funds can be used by eligible entities to expand access to advanced placement incentive programs for low-income students through various activities such as teacher training, curriculum development, and providing books and supplies. Eligible entities must submit an application to the Secretary for the grant, and data collection and reporting on student participation is required annually. The eligible entities receiving grants must report annually to the Secretary on the number of students taking advanced placement courses, tests taken, scores, and demographic information. The Secretary will compile this information and report to Congress. $25,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2000, with additional funding for the following 4 years. SEC. 4. ON-LINE ADVANCED PLACEMENT COURSES. The Secretary will award grants to local educational agencies for on-line advanced placement courses. Agencies can contract with organizations for course provision. Priority is given to agencies serving low-income or rural students without access to such courses. Grant funds can be used for curriculum purchase, teacher training, and course materials. Applications for grants are required. Each local educational agency must submit an application to the Secretary to receive a grant under this section. $10,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2000, with additional funding for the following years. SEC. 5. ADDITIONAL PRIORITIES FOR ADVANCED PLACEMENT. Institutions of higher education must provide information on academic credit for advanced placement test scores to secondary school counselors. They are required to standardize the dissemination of this information within 4 years. Additionally, amendments are made to support gifted and talented students in state and local initiatives. Amendments are made to prioritize programs for gifted and talented students that incorporate advanced placement courses and tests. The upward bound program now focuses on increasing student participation in advanced placement courses. Priority is given to projects that achieve this goal. Amendments prioritize training in advanced placement instruction for grants, contracts, and cooperative agreements. Professional development activities involving advanced placement instruction are emphasized. Advanced Placement Instruction is added as a priority for eligible entities under the Star Schools program. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to encourage delivery of advanced placement instruction to underserved communities and provide education technology for advanced placement instruction. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to promote advanced placement instruction in underserved communities by providing education technology for such instruction. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to promote advanced placement instruction in underserved communities by providing education technology for such instruction. Section 6 defines key terms. The Act defines terms related to advanced placement programs, tests, low-income students, and individuals. The Act defines terms related to advanced placement programs, tests, low-income students, and individuals. It includes definitions for low-income individuals, institutions of higher education, local educational agencies, secondary schools, state educational agencies, and the Secretary of Education. The Secondary Education Act of 1965 defines terms such as Secretary of Education and State, encompassing various regions within the United States and its territories.
